WAMU shuttered DCist without warning last week. The station also took the DCist archives offline. There are some among the WAMU family who recognize the longterm implications for history when journalism archives disappear.

Got curious and looked at which -ists still exist. The two biggest aside from DC were Gothamist and LAist. Both received site redesigns and Gothamist has comments; one of the things that made DCist vital and alive was the self-policing commenter community. It was one of the site’s biggest assets.

DCist lives! (In mothballs, anyway.)

But, at least people can get to the stories.

5. The 'scholarship' backing up 'enrollment cliff' comes from Chicago School economists who have long been opposed to expanding accessibility to public education, especially HigherEd. Of course, it's also conveniently reconcilable with reactionary 'replacement theory' hookum.

4. The 'enrollment cliff' creates a permission structure, sometimes literally a legal loophole, to fire faculty & staff, thus freeing up capital which can be redistributed to private equity via consultancies, EdTech, private contractors, etc.

3. The same private equity firms are deeply (one might say overly) invested in EdTech ventures whose solvency depends on extracting increasingly large contracts from colleges. Many of these ventures are being marketed as efficient replacements for labor (though they aren't).

2. The 'enrollment cliff' is being promoted & literally sold to HigherEd administrators by private consultancies & proprietary data aggregators, all of whom are owned by private equity firms, in most cases KKR, Blackstone, & Vista.

Wage growth is below consumer price growth on an annualized 3 month basis with most recent data, though wage growth is exceeding price growth on a 12-month and 1-month basis.

If employer demand for labor falls or new workers enter to supply, price (wage) should fall.

Private-sector wage growth surged this month to annualized over-month (4.3% from Oct 2.5%), over-3-mo (3.4%). Over-year rate stable: 4.9%.

That’s the extensive quantity (Q) margin. Intensive Q margin is average hours.

Average workweek hours for private-sector stable and normalized. This is down a lot from earlier in the pandemic when employers worked staff longer, instead of hiring.
White and Hispanic men are the furthest off their pre-pandemic employment rates.  In contrast, the share of Black women employed is up.

3.7 million more Americans are out of labor force & not wanting a job on average over the last 3 months vs same months pre-pandemic. 

Increase in the number of older Americans (55+) in this group accounts for 107% of its rise, while fewer younger people are in this status now than before.

When employers struggle to hire, employees' risks in striking ⬇.

When strong consumer demand => more employer $ per job, workers' expected benefit of strike ⬆.

We have both => more labor disputes. 

The number of employees absent due to dispute fell this month but the 3-month average is high.

Mothers of young children have been working at higher rates than ever before. But Nov was the 2nd month after federal, pandemic-era, early childhood care & education funding ended.

Issues may show up first as a rise in employees absent from work due to child care problems. Ticked up in Nov.

The unemployment rate edged down to 0.2 pp to 3.7% in November, and the number of unemployed persons showed little change at 6.3 million. 

This makes 22 consecutive months below 4.0%, typing the length of the spell immediately pre-pandemic.

The employment-population ratio increased by 0.3 percentage point (pp) to 60.5% in November (figure). 

The labor force participation rate was little changed at 62.8% and has been essentially flat since August.

The U.S. labor market remains quite strong despite fiscal and monetary policy brakes.
